description: Five reference sampling regions for Phase 1 data acquisition. One per terrain class. Each region must yield ≥50 non-overlapping 512×512 tiles after Phase 1.3 classification.
naming_convention: MERIT-DEM tiles are named by their SW corner: n25e080 = 25-30°N 80-85°E. S-hemisphere: s05e020 = 5-10°S 20-25°E. W-hemisphere: n35w110 = 35-40°N 105-110°W.

regions.description: Central Himalayas — Nepal/North India border. Classic active orogen, high relief, glaciated peaks with non-glaciated mid-elevation flanks.
filter_rules: Exclude tiles with mean elevation > 4500m (Tibetan Plateau — Cratonic character, not Alpine)
Exclude tiles with GlacialClass=Active unless labelled separately for glacial sub-set
Target elevation range 1500-4500m for main Alpine signal
regions.notes: 4 MERIT tiles yield ~480 theoretical 512×512 slots. After filtering Tibetan Plateau and glaciated summit zones expect ~150-200 usable Alpine tiles. This region is the primary Alpine reference.

regions.description: Congo Basin margins — Democratic Republic of Congo / Congo Republic. Humid tropical fluvial landscape, moderate relief, well-developed dendritic drainage. MAP > 1500mm. Avoids the hyper-flat central várzea problem of the Amazon lowland.
filter_rules: Exclude tiles with local relief (max-min) < 100m — these are central basin flats, not FluvialHumid
Exclude tiles containing large lakes (Tanganyika, Kivu) — lake bed pixels contaminate slope stats
Target valleys and interfluves on basin margins, not Congo River channel itself
regions.notes: Congo basin margins at 500-1500m ASL provide clear FluvialHumid signal with strong drainage networks and measurable Hurst exponents. 5 MERIT tiles give ~600 candidate slots; expect 100-150 usable after filtering.

regions.description: Ahaggar Massif — Tuareg Shield, central Algeria. Exposed Precambrian basement, ancient etch-plain topography. One of the best examples of cratonic morphology in the Geomorpho90m dataset.
filter_rules: Exclude tiles dominated by active erg (sand sea) — Erg du Ténéré margin tiles have aeolian not cratonic morphology
Target rocky hammada and ancient lava plateau surfaces
Identify by roughness < 80m and Geomorpho90m 'flat' + 'slope' class dominance
regions.notes: 3 MERIT tiles give ~360 candidate slots. Ahaggar proper (Tamanrasset province) is compact; expand to n20e000 (Tassili n'Ajjer) if 50 tiles not achievable. Geomorphon distribution should show flat + slope dominance with very low valley/pit frequency.

regions.description: Colorado Plateau — Utah/Arizona/Colorado/New Mexico. Classic ephemeral fluvial landscape: canyon-cut mesas, pediments, bajadas. MAP 200-400mm, strong seasonal precipitation. Canonical FluvialArid reference in geomorphometrics literature.
filter_rules: Exclude tiles in Basin and Range province (south of 35°N) — different tectonic character
Exclude tiles containing Colorado River channel corridor (fluvial incision anomaly)
Target mesa-canyon interfluves: flat tops + incised valleys at 1500-2200m ASL
regions.notes: 2 MERIT tiles give ~240 candidate slots at this latitude (cell size slightly smaller than equatorial tiles). Target tile bbox 35-38°N is sufficient; only the southern half of n35w115 and n35w110 is needed. Canyonlands, Capitol Reef, and Zion sub-regions are ideal. Avoid the Rocky Mountain Front Range (Alpine contamination at eastern edge).

regions.description: US Atlantic coastal plain — North Carolina / Virginia. Classic passive-margin coastal sequence: barrier islands, back-barrier lagoons, coastal plain flats, tidal estuary margins. Abundant Coastal-class terrain with no Alpine contamination.
filter_rules: Exclude Appalachian Piedmont tiles (elevation > 300m, high roughness — these classify as FluvialHumid not Coastal)
Target coastal plain below 200m ASL where Coastal-class geomorphons dominate
regions.notes: 3 MERIT tiles give ~360 candidate slots. Atlantic coastal plain is wide and flat; expect 150+ usable Coastal tiles after filtering ocean and piedmont. Hypsometric Integral will be low (HI ~0.35-0.45 for coastal class). Good passive-margin reference for geomorphon distribution.
